bestBHT.bht: Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus, not wanting to waste time or be delayed by his previous adversaries. His main goal was to reach Jerusalem by the day of Pentecost, showing his dedication and respect for Jewish customs. By choosing not to revisit Ephesus, Paul prioritized spreading the gospel and demonstrating his love for his Jewish brethren.

Henry Alford: We see here that the ship was at Paul’s disposal, and probably hired at Philippi, or rather at Neapolis, for the voyage to Patara.
The expression he had determined is too subjectively strong to allow of our supposing that the Apostle merely followed the previously determined course of a ship in which he took a passage.
He may have been afraid of detention there, owing to the machinations of those who had caused the uproar in ch. xix.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: For Paul had determined to sail by—or 'sail past.'
He was right opposite to it when approaching Chios.

The words imply that there was considerable ground to doubt if he would attain this object—for more than three of the seven weeks from Passover to Pentecost had already expired—and they are inserted evidently to explain why he did not once more visit Ephesus.
Albert Barnes: To sail by Ephesus - The word 'by' in our translation is ambiguous. We say to go by a place, meaning either to take it in our way and to go to it, or to go past it. Here it means the latter."
For he hasted ... - Had he gone to Ephesus, he would probably have been so delayed in his journey that he could not reach Jerusalem at the time of Pentecost.
The day of Pentecost - See the notes on Acts 2:1.
Marvin Vincent: The word carries the suggestion of a waste of time, being compounded with tribw, to rub; to wear out by rubbing."
The sense is nearly equivalent to our expression, fritter away time.
John Calvin: Forasmuch as he did hope that he might do some good in such a great assembly, he would not foreslow [neglect] the opportunity.
Let us know that the worship of the law was not the cause that he made so great haste, but he set before his eyes the edifying of the Church.

They come together when they be called, [which] is not only a token of concord, but also of modesty; for they were many; yet doth it not irk them to obey one apostle of Christ, whom they knew to be endued with singular gifts.
Philip Schaff: He would not himself revisit the old scene of his ‘two years’ labour, lest the many friends and their pressing solicitations, and the varied questions they would of course have laid before him, should have delayed his voyage...
He knew such a mark of respect for the sacred Hebrew custom would be pleasing to the stricter Jewish Christians.

...thus spread abroad in all lands the great fact that even the Gentile members of the new and suspected sect of Christians loved, with a deep love, their Jewish brethren who dwelt under the shadow of the temple on Mount Zion.
Archibald T. Robertson: Either Paul controlled the ship or the captain was willing to oblige him.
The verb τριβω, to rub, to wear out by rubbing, lends itself to the idea of wasting time.
Paul wanted to be there for the whole day.
John Gill: he chose not to stop there, fearing he should be detained by the brethren there
for he hasted, if it were possible, for him to be at Jerusalem the day of Pentecost

his great desire to be at the feast of Pentecost was not in order to keep that feast, according to the usage of the Jews; but that he might have an opportunity of preaching the Gospel to a great number of Jews, out of all countries, whom he knew would come to that feast.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus, rather than stopping there, to avoid any potential delay caused by his previous adversaries. He wanted to make the most of his time and not waste it, frittering away days as the ship rubbed on. It is clear that either Paul had control over the ship or the captain was willing to accommodate him. Going directly to Jerusalem was of utmost importance to Paul, as he wanted to reach there by the day of Pentecost. By choosing not to revisit Ephesus, Paul avoided potential distractions from his journey and instead focused on spreading the message of the gospel and showing his love for the Jewish brethren.

Paul decided to sail by Ephesus rather than stopping there, as he did not want to waste time or be delayed by his previous adversaries. He wanted to make the most of his journey and reach Jerusalem in time for the day of Pentecost. Paul's decision showed his love for the Jewish brethren and his dedication to spreading the gospel. By avoiding a visit to Ephesus, he could focus solely on his mission and avoid potential distractions along the way.

Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus rather than stopping there, possibly due to fear of detention caused by his adversaries in the past. He didn't want to waste time, as the ship rubbed on and the weeks passed. His main goal was to reach Jerusalem by the day of Pentecost, showing his dedication and respect for Jewish customs. By choosing not to revisit Ephesus, Paul prioritized spreading the gospel and demonstrating his love for his Jewish brethren.

By choosing not to revisit Ephesus, Paul prioritized spreading the gospel and demonstrating his love for his Jewish brethren.

Paul had determined to sail past Ephesus, not wanting to waste time or be delayed by his previous adversaries. His main goal was to reach Jerusalem by the day of Pentecost, showing his dedication and respect for Jewish customs. By choosing not to revisit Ephesus, Paul prioritized spreading the gospel and demonstrating his love for his Jewish brethren.
